column1: The regulation of blood glucose levels is crucial for maintaining homeostasis in the body
Insulin is a hormone produced by the pancreas that helps cells absorb glucose from the bloodstream
When blood glucose levels rise, such as after a meal, insulin is secreted to facilitate glucose entry into cells
On the other hand, glucagon is another hormone released by the pancreas, primarily when blood glucose levels are low
Glucagon signals the liver to convert stored glycogen into glucose and release it into the blood
During times of stress, the body releases adrenaline and cortisol, which have opposing effects on glucose regulation
Adrenaline prompts the liver to release stored glucose into the bloodstream, raising blood sugar levels
Cortisol, meanwhile, has a more prolonged effect, encouraging the breakdown of proteins into glucose and suppressing insulin production
The interplay between insulin, glucagon, and stress hormones ensures that blood glucose levels remain stable despite varying demands
When this system is disrupted, as in diabetes, it can lead to either high or low blood sugar levels, causing serious health issues
Therefore, understanding this hormonal interplay is essential for managing and preventing metabolic disorders
